body: When you do a `/whois` on a group peer you now see their real IP address listed with the rest of their info. If they aren't accepting direct connections then you will see a placeholder value indicating as much. If you `/whois` yourself, you'll see either your own IP address or a placeholder value, depending on whether or not you're accepting direct connections. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/TokTok/toxic/238)

comment_data.body: This will make it so you can't release to Debian, because you're going to unconditionally rely on unstable APIs. Is that intentional?
Should this be a "has header" compile time check (make) ?

I'd make it an optional flag in the build. It's going to depend on experimental APIs that won't be stable across minor or patch releases, so it'll break in hilarious ways when Debian updates toxcore but not toxic or vice versa.
or, less portable, dlopen()+dlsym() symbol searching (might not work if not exported) + needs to be conditional too.
That won't know the type of the function, which may change.
Good point. Added a makefile option that's disabled by default, but enabled in the static build.

commit.message:
Add IP address to group whois info

When you do a /whois on a group peer you now see their
real IP address listed with the rest of their info.
If they aren't accepting direct connections then you
will see a placeholder value indicating as much.
If you /whois yourself, you'll see either your own
IP address or a placeholder value, depending on whether
or not you're accepting direct connections.

If they aren't accepting direct connections then you

If you /whois yourself, you'll see either your own
